Great ones want their careers enabled, want you to have their back, and want no politics.  That's about it.  Let them run.

Good ones want many other, varied things. And need much more.

1096007389025894400.text: "Nothing else matters" I wanted to say ;)

1096002155813720071.text: 25) Let me know if you have thoughts or feedback on the above!

1096002154727391232.text: 24) With most other monetisation tactics, a marketplace runs the risk of discouraging the demand, supply or both, if introduced before liquidity; some thoughts on monetization here:https://medium.com/point-nine-news/10-marketplace-monetisation-strategies-7d2371afd7d5 …

1096002153687273473.text: 23) On monetisation & liquidity: as liquidity goes up, so does the ability to monetise the marketplace; focus on scaling liquidity before focusing on making money with it; before that I would suggest to only employ commission-based monetization or SaaS fees

1096002152517038080.text: 22) Hack #1 for bootstrapping liquidity: in early days you may want to limit the scope of the marketplace. It is, better to focus on one geo or category and build out liquidity from there rather than tackle various categories or geos at the same time; FB the most famous example

1096002151543947264.text: 21) Carefully scaling both sides and monitoring the above metrics so that both supply and demand are kept happy is critical for a marketplace’s success

1096002150470176770.text:
20) Metrics for measuring supply relevance: retention rates, activity cohorts and churn rates (high relevance and liquidity drive more frequent use), volume of business per supplier, ideally expressed as % of capacity,
conversion rates or “fill rates”

1096002149442617344.text: 19) Another “hack” is to build a software enabled marketplace, like @eversports, and deliver value with software features; once there is a sufficient supply base, a demand side can be added to the equation, a marketplace kicks in and there is even more value for the supply

1096002148536590336.text: 18) You can "hack" supply by paying them directly to list on your marketplace; Uber does this with drivers in some places

1096002147525758979.text: 17) For labour based marketplaces such as Uber or Preply, think about how many hours of employment and associated revenue will you be able to generate for the supply to keep them loyal to the platform

1096002146410135562.text: 16) Key to understanding supplier relevance, is to understand their total capacity / revenues of suppliers and the estimate how many % of that a platform can cover. The anecdotal rule of thumb is that 20-30% is the minimum for being very relevant and able to keep supply around

1096002145323765761.text: 15) Metrics to measure demand success: platform specific availab ratios, like time-to-pick-up; generic KPIs: conversion rate from request / search to transaction (higher success rates at higher liquidity), retention, activity cohorts, churn, NPS (liquidity drives satisfaction)

1096002144363335680.text: 14) For demand: while requirements will vary and be industry specific, it will likely boil down to ensuring that there is sufficient supply either within a certain geographical reach, time and/or within a certain category, often at a specific price

1096002143394385921.text: 13) These examples show that for managing liquidity you need to answer two questions and find metrics for them (1) What needs to happen for a transaction to be successful for the demand side? and (2) How many transactions need to happen to be relevant for the supply?

1096002142412914688.text: 12) @PreplyCom uses a similar methodology to manage the supply of various tutor categories across time zones. Likewise, eBay manages supply and demand on a per category basis. They must ensure that there is sufficient supply (and demand) in each of the relevant categories

1096002141414658048.text: 11) @docplanner wants to make sure that you can find a highly rated doctor in the specific area you are looking for, with availabilities within a certain time frame; they measure the average fill-rates of doctor slots by area and specialty/category and manage supply accordingly

1096002140441587712.text: 10) Food delivery co's also look at “time to delivery”; they must make sure there is a sufficient # of restaurants and drivers within a geo; they must also ensure diversity in terms of restaurant categories, while restaurants must be able to expect to get a meaningful # of orders

1096002139401449473.text: 9) Time-to-pick-up, must be weighed against utilization of drivers. Providing near to instant time-to-pickup requires a high number of drivers, many of whom won't be kept busy enough to stay happy and loyal to the platform. So reve per driver is likely another KPI they look at

1096002138386452480.text: 8) It seems that Uber is optimizing for “time-to-pick-up” within a certain geo, aiming to have enough drivers to results in a pick-up within X minutes. If pick-ups take too long, Uber needs to increase the number of drivers

1096002137392365568.text: 7) While GMV, number of listings, etc. can be used uniformly across marketplaces, the actual drivers of success can vary a lot and can be very unique and marketplace specific. Let's look at some examples:

1096002136347955200.text: 6) It gets trickier when we try to measure and drive liquidity. Startups tend to focus on metrics like GMV, # of buyers/sellers/listings to measure progress. While helpful, these do not capture the essence of interactions on the platform and rather measure the end result of it

1096002135169351680.text: 5) @sanguit characterizes liquidity as a state in which there is a minimum threshold of producers and consumers on the marketplace and there is a high expectation of transactions taking place https://platformed.info/online-marketplace-metrics/ …

1096002134032699392.text: 4) @JamesCurrier of @NFXGuild defines it as the probability of selling something you list or of finding something you are looking forhttps://www.sharetribe.com/academy/network-effects-marketplaces-james-currier/ …

1096002132933779456.text: 3) The idea of liquidity is crucial for marketplaces; it is the P in the marketplace's PMF. Liquidity is THE product marketplaces sell and without liquidity, a marketplace makes no sense, has no product and thus no PMF. "Nothing matters" as Metallica would say ;)

1096002131780358144.text: 2) There is a bit of "I know it when I see it" to it (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_know_it_when_I_see_it …), but we should be able to do better!
